Title: GENEVA, Switzerland – The International Committee of the Red Cross (ICRC) has announced a record budget for 2023, reflecting the explosion of global conflicts and violence that has put unprecedented pressure on the humanitarian aid organization.The ICRC said on Thursday that its budget for next year had risen to 2.8 billion Swiss francs ($2.8 billion), up from 2.2 billion francs in 2022, as it seeks to cope with the escalating crisis.“The scale and brutality of the violence in many conflict zones have left us with no choice but to respond with a significant increase in our budget and our efforts,” said ICRC President, Peter Maurer.The record budget will be used to support the organization's work in providing humanitarian aid and protection to millions of people affected by war, persecution, and natural disasters. The ICRC provides assistance to people affected by conflicts in places like Syria, Yemen, Afghanistan, and Somalia, among others.The organization will also use the funds to step up its efforts to protect and assist civilians caught up in the fighting, including by providing medical care, shelter, and food.“The ICRC cannot solve these conflicts, but we can help alleviate the suffering of those caught up in them,” Maurer said.The ICRC has faced criticism in recent years for its decision to limit its operations in some areas due to security concerns. The organization has come under attack from armed groups in places like Syria and Yemen, and its staff have been killed or kidnapped.However, Maurer said the ICRC was committed to doing everything possible to assist people in need, despite the challenges and risks involved.“The ICRC's unwavering commitment to humanity is what sets us apart,” he said.

DAMASCUS, SYRIA - The United Nations' top aid official has expressed concern over the state of relief operations in Syria, citing the "overwhelming" scale of the humanitarian crisis.Speaking to reporters in Damascus, Stephen O'Malley, the UN's Under-Secretary-General for Humanitarian Affairs and Emergency Relief, praised the efforts of aid workers on the ground, but warned that the sheer magnitude of the crisis was "overwhelming" the relief operations."We have seen an unprecedented level of humanitarian need in Syria, with over 100,000 people killed and over 2 million refugees," O'Malley said. "The scale of the crisis is simply overwhelming. It is one of the largest humanitarian operations in the world, and we are doing everything we can to respond."O'Malley said that the UN was working with a wide range of partners, including non-governmental organizations and governments, to provide assistance to those in need in Syria."We have a massive operation under way, with over 700 staff working in the country," he said. "We are doing our best to get aid to those who need it, but it is a difficult and dangerous environment, and we face many challenges."Despite the challenges, O'Malley emphasized the importance of continuing to provide assistance to those affected by the crisis in Syria."We must never forget that these are innocent people who are suffering as a result of this conflict," he said.

Juba, South Sudan - In a major milestone for the young nation, the South Sudanese government announced the release of more than 300 child soldiers from various armed groups. The children, who were between the ages of 8 and 18, were recruited into the armed groups mainly due to poverty and lack of education.The release of the child soldiers was made possible through the efforts of various organizations and government bodies, including the United Nations Children's Fund (UNICEF), the United Nations Mission in South Sudan (UNMISS), and the government of South Sudan.According to UNICEF, the released children will be provided with psychological and medical support, as well as education and vocational training to help them reintegrate into their communities.South Sudan has been embroiled in conflict since December 2013, leading to the displacement of millions of people and a significant rise in the number of child soldiers. The release of these child soldiers is seen as a positive step towards peace and stability in the young nation.In a statement, UNICEF Representative in South Sudan, Hamid El-Bashir, expressed his appreciation for the government's efforts in releasing the child soldiers and called for continued efforts to end the recruitment of children by armed groups."We hope that this will be a first step in a sustained effort to end the use of children by armed groups in South Sudan," El-Bashir said. "The release of these children is a critical step towards ensuring their safety and well-being, and we urge all armed groups to follow suit."The release of the child soldiers comes at a time when the government of South Sudan and various armed groups are engaged in peace talks aimed at ending the conflict.

The death toll from flash floods in Iran has risen to 44, officials said on Saturday.The disaster occurred in the eastern province of Sistan and Baluchistan, where heavy rains caused flooding and landslides.The governor of Sistan and Baluchistan, Mohammad Ali Jafari, said that efforts were underway to rescue people stranded in flooded areas and provide aid to those affected.The government has declared a state of emergency in the affected areas, and army and emergency services have been deployed to help with relief efforts.The Iranian Red Crescent Society has also been mobilized to help those in need.The flash floods have also caused damage to infrastructure and homes, and authorities are assessing the extent of the damage.The floods have also disrupted transportation in the affected areas, with many roads closed due to the weather conditions.Iran is prone to flash floods due to its geography and climate, and officials have urged people to be prepared for such disasters.The government has launched a campaign to raise awareness about disaster preparedness and response.

ISLAMABAD, Sep 22 (ONN) - President General Pervez Musharraf pledged Pakistan's full effort to curb Afghan terrorists threatening peace in the region.Musharraf made the assurance during a meeting with visiting Afghan Foreign Minister Abdullah Abdullah, who called on him here on Wednesday.Pakistan and Afghanistan share a 2,600-km porous border and the cross-border movement of militants has been a major concern for both the countries.Musharraf said that Pakistan will take necessary steps to check infiltration of terrorists across the border.

Despite the ongoing political tensions in Lebanon, the United Nations has called for free and fair elections in the country. In a statement issued by the UN Special Coordinator for Lebanon, Sigrid Kaag, the international organization expressed its commitment to supporting the Lebanese people in their pursuit of democratic governance."The United Nations remains committed to supporting the Lebanese people in their pursuit of democratic governance, and in this context, we urge all parties to ensure that the upcoming parliamentary elections are free and fair," Kaag said in the statement.Lebanon has been in a state of political deadlock for months, with protests and demonstrations regularly taking place in the country. The political situation has made it difficult for the Lebanese people to have faith in their government and its institutions.The UN Special Coordinator emphasized the importance of free and fair elections as a means of ensuring that the will of the people is reflected in the composition of the Lebanese parliament. "Holding credible and transparent elections is essential to rebuilding confidence in the democratic process and to ensuring that the voices of all Lebanese citizens are heard," Kaag added.The UN call for free and fair elections in Lebanon comes at a crucial time, as the country prepares for parliamentary elections in the coming weeks. The international organization has urged all parties to work together to ensure that the elections are conducted in a peaceful and secure environment, and that all eligible voters are able to participate without fear of intimidation or violence.

The Amidst the ongoing trade tensions between the United States and France, a mysterious disappearance has taken place. The gifted oak tree, which was presented to President Trump by French President Emmanuel Macron during their meeting last month, has vanished without a trace.The tree, which was grown from an acorn gifted to Macron by his wife, was said to symbolize the strong friendship between the two leaders. However, it appears that the symbolism was short-lived, as the tree is now nowhere to be found.The White House has made a statement claiming that the tree was always meant to be a temporary fixture and was removed after the meeting, but many are skeptical of this explanation. The French government, on the other hand, insists that they were not informed of any such plan and believe that the tree has been stolen.The disappearance of the oak tree has sparked a diplomatic row between the two countries, with Macron reportedly demanding answers from Trump during their call last week.

US Wants Treatment, Not Jailing, of Drug UsersA recent survey conducted by the Pew Research Center has shown that the majority of Americans believe that drug users should be treated for addiction rather than being jailed. The survey, which was conducted on a representative sample of over 4,000 US adults, found that 62% of respondents felt that drug users should receive treatment, while only 33% believed that they should be arrested and punished.The survey also found that there was a significant partisan divide on the issue, with 73% of Democrats believing that drug users should receive treatment, compared to 51% of Republicans. However, there was also a majority of Independents who supported treatment over jail time, with 59% agreeing with this view.The findings of the survey are in line with a growing movement towards treating drug addiction as a public health issue, rather than a criminal justice issue. Many experts argue that punitive approaches to drug use, such as imprisonment, are ineffective in addressing the root causes of addiction and often lead to further harm to individuals and communities.Instead, many advocate for a harm reduction approach that focuses on providing access to social and medical services, such as counseling, therapy, and clean needles, to help individuals overcome their addiction. This approach is supported by evidence from countries that have implemented such policies, which have seen a reduction in drug-related crime and an improvement in public health outcomes.In response to the survey findings, some experts have called on policymakers to prioritize investments in drug treatment and prevention programs, rather than relying on punitive measures to address drug use. They argue that this approach would not only benefit individuals struggling with addiction, but also contribute to safer and healthier communities overall.In conclusion, the Pew Research Center's survey results reflect a growing recognition of the need to address drug addiction as a health issue, rather than a criminal justice issue.

Bhutan and the Maldives have successfully eliminated measles, the World Health Organization (WHO) announced on Thursday.The WHO Verifiable Task Manager (VTM) had reported in June that both countries had not had any new measles cases since the last outbreak in 2016 and 2017, respectively.According to the WHO, the two countries achieved this milestone through high-quality vaccination coverage and strong surveillance systems.Measles is a highly contagious viral disease that can cause serious health complications, including pneumonia, diarrhea, and encephalitis. The disease can also lead to death in some cases.The WHO has been working with member states to control and eliminate measles globally. The organization recommends that all countries ensure that at least 95% of their population is vaccinated against measles to prevent outbreaks.Bhutan and the Maldives are the latest countries to achieve this goal, and their success shows that eliminating measles is possible even in low-income countries with limited resources.The WHO congratulates both countries on this achievement and encourages them to continue surveillance to ensure that the virus does not re-emerge.The organization also calls on other countries to redouble their efforts to achieve the same goal and prevent the spread of measles globally.

Washington, DC - A top US diplomat has urged the Trump administration to support Ethiopia's "fragile" political reforms, which have been taking place since Prime Minister Abiy Ahmed came to power in April 2018.Speaking at a recent event hosted by the Center for Strategic and International Studies (CSIS), Principal Deputy Assistant Secretary of State for African Affairs, Michelle Bekkering, said that while Ethiopia has made significant progress in political and economic reforms, there is still much work to be done."The reforms that have taken place in Ethiopia have been significant, but they are also fragile," Bekkering said. "And so the United States, and the international community, really need to be supportive of the government of Ethiopia and the progress that they've made."Bekkering highlighted the importance of Ethiopia to the region and to the US, citing the country's role as a regional power and a key player in the fight against terrorism. She also emphasized the need for continued US engagement in the country, and called on American companies to invest in Ethiopia's growing economy.However, she also acknowledged that there were challenges ahead, including the need to address ethnic tensions and to ensure that all Ethiopians had a voice in the political process."There are still concerns about the political space and the ability of citizens to express their views freely," Bekkering said. "We still have concerns about the freedom of the media and the ability for journalists to do their jobs without fear of intimidation or reprisal."Ethiopia, which has a population of over 100 million people, is one of the fastest-growing economies in the world.

Washington, D.C. – In a move that has been long awaited by many, top officials from the United States and Russia have signaled their desire to improve relations between the two countries.The announcement was made following a meeting between US Secretary of State Rex Tillerson and Russian Foreign Minister Sergey Lavrov in Moscow. During their talks, both officials expressed a willingness to work towards improving the strained relationship between the two nations.The US and Russia have been at odds over a number of issues, including the conflicts in Ukraine and Syria, as well as allegations of cyber attacks and interference in each other's political processes. However, with the recent signal of a desire to improve relations, many are hopeful that a new chapter in US-Russian relations can be opened.There is no word yet on what specific steps will be taken to improve relations, but both sides have expressed a commitment to working towards a more positive and productive relationship. The two nations have a long and complex history, and it remains to be seen how successful their efforts to improve relations will be.While some are cautiously optimistic about the development, others remain skeptical and believe that the road to improved US-Russian relations will be a difficult and long one. Only time will tell if the latest signal of a desire to improve relations will lead to concrete results.

WASHINGTON D.C. – President Donald Trump has filed a lawsuit to block a subpoena issued by the House Oversight Committee for his financial records.The suit, filed in the U.S. District Court for the District of Columbia on Monday, argues that the subpoena is unconstitutional and violates the President’s privileges under the U.S. Constitution.The House Oversight Committee, led by Democratic Congressman Elijah Cummings, issued the subpoena last month for financial records from Trump’s accounting firm, Mazars USA.In his lawsuit, Trump claims that the subpoena is a “politically motivated fishing expedition” aimed at obtaining personal and privileged information.“The subpoena is unlawful and unenforceable, and the Committee lacks the authority to demand that the President disclose his private financial information,” Trump’s legal team argued in the complaint.The legal battle sets up a potential court fight between the branches of government, with the President and the Democratic-led House locked in a struggle over the limits of Congress’s power to investigate the President.The case is likely to be closely watched by both sides of the political aisle, as it could have implications for future investigations into the President’s financial dealings.

Washington, Oct. 1 (Bloomberg) - The top US general said that enemies could misunderstand the debate over the presence of American troops in Iraq. "There's a real risk that our enemies will misunderstand the debate going on in this country and think that we're weak," General Peter Pace, chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff, said in an interview. "That's why we have to do everything we can to communicate to our enemies that we're strong and united." Pace, who is the military's top officer, spoke with reporters at the Pentagon on Sept. 30 about the situation in Iraq. The US has about 135,000 troops in Iraq, and President George W. Bush has called for a gradual withdrawal of American forces over time.

WASHINGTON, July 18 - The US envoy to Sudan said on Thursday that he would seek to expand the scope of the Comprehensive Peace Agreements signed by Sudan and southern rebels earlier this year."We are seeking to make the peace more comprehensive, to bring more people into the process," said the envoy, Cornelius "Cob" Wyckoff, in an interview with Reuters.Wyckoff said he would seek to broaden the peace deals, which ended two decades of civil war between the government and rebels in the south, to include other regions of the country that have suffered from conflict."There are other areas of Sudan that are in need of peace, and we want to make sure that peace is extended to them," Wyckoff said. "We believe that the CPA offers a framework for resolving conflicts in other parts of the country."The envoy said that the US would work with other international partners, including the United Nations, to support the implementation of the peace agreements and promote reconciliation and healing in Sudan."The international community has a role to play in helping to bring stability and peace to Sudan," Wyckoff said.

Yemen, a country with a long history of tribalism, is currently facing one of its most challenging times. The tribal system, which has been a fundamental part of Yemeni society for centuries, is now contributing to the deepening conflict in the country.Yemen is divided into various tribal confederations, each with its own traditions, customs, and laws. These tribes have long maintained their own autonomous governance, which has led to a lack of centralized authority and government control over certain regions of the country.The current conflict in Yemen has further exacerbated the divisions between the different tribes. The conflict began in 2015, when the Houthi rebellion, backed by Iran, took control of much of the country, including the capital, Sana'a. Since then, the country has been divided between the government forces, backed by a Saudi-led coalition, and the Houthi rebels.The conflict has created a power vacuum in many parts of the country, which has been filled by tribal leaders. These leaders have used their influence and power to further their own interests, often at the expense of the broader population. The lack of a strong central government has only strengthened the position of these tribal leaders, and has made it more difficult for the government to maintain control.The tribal system has also made it more difficult for humanitarian organizations to operate in the country. Humanitarian workers have been subject to kidnapping and other forms of violence, and many of the areas they need to access are controlled by tribal leaders who may not be sympathetic to their cause.The situation in Yemen is complex and multifaceted, but the tribal system is undoubtedly a contributing factor to the deepening conflict. The international community has been working to bring an end to the conflict, but it will likely require a long-term solution that addresses the underlying issues of tribalism and governance in Yemen.

In his State of the Union address this week, President Trump made several claims that have sparked controversy. Let's fact-check some of the key statements he made.1. The President claimed that the economy is the best it has ever been. While the economy has been strong in recent years, it is not the best it has ever been. In fact, there have been several periods in American history when the economy has performed better, such as in the 1960s.2. Trump also claimed that his administration has created 7 million jobs. While it is true that the economy has added jobs during Trump's presidency, the President's number is an exaggeration. The actual number of jobs created is closer to 2 million.3. The President also claimed that he has cut regulations more than any other President in history. While it is true that the Trump Administration has rolled back many regulations, this claim is not supported by data. In fact, the Obama Administration was the most active in terms of creating regulations, while the Trump Administration has actually increased the number of regulations.4. Trump also claimed that his administration has achieved the "greatest progress in the history of our country" in terms of addressing the opioid crisis. While it is true that the Administration has taken some steps to address the crisis, this claim is misleading. In reality, the opioid crisis continues to be a major problem in the United States and has not been effectively addressed.5. Finally, the President claimed that his Administration has "started the construction of a wall on the southern border". While it is true that some construction of the wall has taken place, the claim that it has been "started" is misleading. The wall remains incomplete and many parts of it have yet to be built.In conclusion, while the President made some accurate statements in his State of the Union address, he also made several exaggerated or misleading claims. As journalists, it is important to fact-check the statements made by public figures and hold them accountable for their accuracy.

WASHINGTON - The Environmental Protection Agency (EPA) must strengthen its oversight of state drinking water programs, an internal watchdog said in a report published on Wednesday. The report came after a water crisis in Flint, Michigan, where the city's drinking water became contaminated with lead in 2014.According to the report, the EPA's Office of Water, which is responsible for overseeing state drinking water programs, did not effectively oversee the Flint water crisis. The office failed to identify and address risks to public health and the environment in a timely manner, the report said."We found that EPA's Office of Water failed to recognize and respond to the severity of the Flint water crisis in a timely manner," the report said. "Specifically, the office did not effectively use its regulatory authorities to provide technical assistance, conduct enforcement activities, or provide emergency funding to support the City of Flint's drinking water efforts."The report recommended that the EPA improve its risk management processes and increase its engagement with states, tribes and local governments to identify and address risks to drinking water systems.The EPA should also develop a system to track and respond to drinking water emergencies in real-time and increase its transparency and communication with the public, the report said."EPA should take a more proactive and collaborative approach to working with states, tribes, and local governments to identify and address drinking water risks," the report said. "By doing so, the agency can better protect public health and the environment and prevent future drinking water crises like the one in Flint."

BAGHDAD - Iraqi security forces have arrested a senior insurgent linked to a series of car bombings in the capital, officials said Sunday.The suspect, who was not identified, is believed to have played a key role in planning and executing the attacks, which have caused dozens of casualties in recent weeks.The arrest was made during a joint operation by Iraqi security forces and U.S. troops in Baghdad on Saturday, the officials said.The insurgent is suspected of having ties to al-Qaida in Iraq, the officials said.The latest arrests come as Iraqi and U.S. forces continue to ramp up security measures in Baghdad and other violence-plagued areas of the country, in an effort to stem the tide of sectarian violence and insurgent attacks.According to a senior U.S. military official, the operation is part of ongoing efforts to disrupt the insurgent network responsible for much of the violence in Iraq.The official, who spoke on condition of anonymity, said the operation is aimed at "severely diminishing" the ability of the insurgents to carry out attacks against innocent Iraqi civilians and coalition forces.The arrests follow a series of high-profile operations against suspected insurgents in recent weeks, including the capture of the man believed to be the mastermind behind the bombing of a revered Shiite mosque in Samarra last month.The latest operation is expected to further ratchet up pressure on the insurgents, who have seen their strongholds in and around Baghdad come under increasing military and intelligence scrutiny in recent months.The crackdown has already had some success in reducing the number of car bombings in the capital, although sectarian tensions and violence remain high.

Ronald Reagan, the former US president who died in 2004, has returned to the campaign trail - as a hologram.The digital version of the 40th US president was unveiled at a rally for the Republican candidate for the California governorship, John Cox, on Tuesday.Reagan's holographic image appeared on stage alongside Cox, who was also joined by Nancy Reagan, the former first lady who died in 2016.The hologram was used to promote the California Republican Party, and was created by a company that specializes in digital imaging and 3D projection."The technology has advanced to the point where we can actually create a hologram of someone who has passed away, and in this case, President Reagan," said former White House press secretary Tony Snow, who introduced the hologram at the rally."It's not entirely clear what Reagan would have thought of this technology," Snow added, "but I think he would have been amused by it."The use of holograms to bring back historical figures has become increasingly popular in recent years, with other notable examples including a holographic performance by rapper Tupac Shakur at the Coachella music festival in 2012.

East Timor's journey to independence is almost complete. On May 20, the United Nations will declare the country's statehood, marking the end of a long and tumultuous process that began with the ousting of Indonesian occupying forces in 1999.The milestone has been a long time coming, and East Timorese are understandably ecstatic. "This is a momentous occasion, one that we have been waiting for a long time," says Jose Ramos Horta, leader of the country's main opposition party. "We hope that the world will recognize the progress we have made and continue to support our development."International recognition of East Timor's independence has been a slow process, but has gained momentum over the past year. In November, the United States became the first major power to recognize East Timor as an independent nation, followed by Japan and the Philippines.The United Nations has played a crucial role in East Timor's journey to independence. In 1975, Indonesia invaded the country, and East Timor was later annexed by Indonesia in 1989. The United Nations intervened in 1999, after militias backed by the Indonesian government went on a rampage, leaving thousands dead and displacing hundreds of thousands.The United Nations Transitional Administration in East Timor (UNTAET) was established to oversee the territory's transition to independence. As part of this process, the United Nations has helped organize elections and facilitate negotiations between rival political factions.East Timorese are hopeful that the international community will continue to support their country's development. "The United Nations has been a great help to us," says Manuel Tilman, a East Timorese political leader. "We hope that the world will continue to watch over us as we build our future."The road ahead for East Timor is not without challenges.

TEHRAN - Iran's national airline, Iran Air, has announced plans to purchase 30 new Boeing jets to update its aging fleet.The announcement was made by the CEO of Iran Air, Farzaneh Sharafbaf, during a press conference in Tehran."This is a major step forward for Iran Air," Sharafbaf said. "We are excited to add these state-of-the-art aircraft to our fleet and offer our passengers a more comfortable and efficient flying experience."The deal is expected to be finalized in the coming weeks, with delivery of the planes set to begin in the next year.The purchase of the new planes is part of Iran Air's efforts to expand its international presence and increase tourism to the country."Iran has a rich cultural heritage and beautiful landscapes that we believe will be of interest to travelers from around the world," Sharafbaf said. "We hope to attract more visitors to Iran by offering a high-quality air travel experience."The new Boeing jets will replace older aircraft in Iran Air's fleet, which has been struggling with maintenance issues in recent years.The airline has been working to improve its safety record in recent months, including implementing new training programs for its pilots and crew."We are committed to ensuring that our passengers feel safe and secure when they fly with Iran Air," Sharafbaf said.

BEIJING - Chinese authorities have arrested a student leader at a prestigious university in Beijing for celebrating the birthday of Mao Zedong, the founding father of modern China.The student, who is a member of a local Marxist student group, was detained by police on Thursday while distributing leaflets on the campus of Beijing Normal University to mark the anniversary of Mao's birthday on December 26.According to reports, the student was accused of "inciting subversion of state power" and "disturbing public order" by the university's public security bureau.The move has sparked criticism from some quarters, with some viewing it as an attempt by the authorities to suppress political dissent and stifle free speech.The student's arrest is the latest in a series of incidents in which Chinese authorities have cracked down on those who they perceive as being politically sensitive or a threat to social stability.In recent months, the government has stepped up its efforts to control online discourse and restrict access to foreign media, in addition to tightening its grip on religious and ethnic minorities in the restive Xinjiang region.The situation has raised concerns among human rights groups and foreign governments about the state of political freedoms in China.However, the Chinese government has defended its actions, saying that they are necessary to maintain social stability and national security.

At least 18 people have been killed and many more injured in an earthquake that struck the southwestern Chinese province of Sichuan on Monday. The quake had a magnitude of 6.5 and its epicenter was in the town of Yingxiu, according to Chinese officials.The earthquake caused significant damage to buildings and infrastructure in the affected areas, with many homes and buildings reduced to rubble. Rescue teams have been dispatched to the region, and efforts are under way to provide relief to those affected by the disaster.The Chinese government has declared a state of emergency in the affected areas, and the country's premier, Li Keqiang, has arrived in the region to oversee the response efforts.

US-backed forces fighting the Islamic State (IS) in Syria have admitted to facing "difficulties" in their operations against the terror group.In a statement released yesterday, the Syrian Democratic Forces (SDF) said that they have been making progress in their battle against IS, but they are still facing challenges, particularly in the areas of Raqqa and Deir ez-Zor."Our forces have been making progress against the IS in Syria, but there are still difficulties in some areas," the SDF statement read. "We are determined to continue our fight against the terror group until its complete defeat."The SDF is a coalition of Kurdish and Arab militias that are backed by the US-led international coalition. They have been leading the fight against IS in Syria, with the help of the coalition's airstrikes.The SDF's admission of difficulties in their operations against IS comes days after the terror group launched a counter-attack in Raqqa, which is considered as the de facto capital of the IS caliphate. The attack killed dozens of people and injured hundreds.The SDF's statement also urged the international community to continue supporting their efforts in the fight against IS. "We call on the international community to continue its support for our forces in their fight against the IS," the statement read.The SDF's battle against IS has been ongoing for several years, and they have made significant gains in recent months. Earlier this year, they captured the IS stronghold of Manbij, and they have been advancing towards Raqqa and Deir ez-Zor.However, the SDF's admission of difficulties in their operations against IS highlights the challenges that remain in the fight against the terror group.

Hillary Clinton caused a stir on Friday when she said that "half" of Donald Trump's supporters "belong in the basket of deplorables." The comment was made at a fundraiser in New York City, where the Democratic presidential nominee was speaking with donors about the challenges she faces in the campaign. According to a video of the event obtained by NBC News, Clinton said that "to just be grossly generalistic, you could put half of Trump's supporters into what I call the 'basket of deplorables.'" She went on to explain that this group includes "people who are racist, sexist, homophobic, xenophobic, Islamophobic—you name it. And they are not going to support you. And they have problems with women, with gays and lesbians, with minorities, they are not for immigration, they are not for anything that would make America great again in their view because they don't want to change anything."

"Nairobi, Kenya: Kenya has become a pioneer in the world of finance by introducing a new way to transfer money. Kenyans can now use their mobile phones to transfer funds to anyone in the country, regardless of their bank.This revolutionary new system, called M-Pesa, has been embraced by many Kenyans, who have been frustrated by the long lines and high fees associated with traditional banking. With M-Pesa, users can easily send and receive money with just a few clicks on their mobile phones."This is a huge step forward for financial inclusion in Kenya," said Bitange Ndemo, the Permanent Secretary in the Ministry of Information and Communications. "With M-Pesa, even those who do not have bank accounts can now participate in the financial system."M-Pesa was developed by Vodafone and Safaricom, Kenya's largest mobile network operator. The service is based on the use of a "virtual wallet", which can be topped up with money from a bank account or other sources.The Kenyan government has welcomed the new system, which has the potential to spur economic growth and help lift people out of poverty."M-Pesa is an excellent example of innovation and partnership between the private and public sectors," said Ndemo. "It has the potential to be a game-changer for Kenya's financial system."M-Pesa has already been adopted by many Kenyans, who have praised its convenience and ease of use.

Datuk Seri Abdullah Ahmad Badawi, former Prime Minister of Malaysia, has condemned former US President George W. Bush and former UK Prime Minister Tony Blair as "war criminals" for their role in the Iraq War.In an exclusive interview with Al Jazeera, Abdullah said that the invasion of Iraq in 2003 was "a crime against humanity" and that Bush and Blair should be held accountable for their actions."The invasion of Iraq was a violation of international law. It was a war of aggression, and as such, it was a crime against humanity," Abdullah said. "Bush and Blair should be held accountable for their actions, and they should be tried as war criminals."

A top US official has said that the US administration is seeking a dialogue with China over the Terminal High Altitude Area Defense (THAAD) missile defense system. The official, who spoke to reporters on condition of anonymity, said that the US was keen to engage in a constructive dialogue with Beijing in order to address its concerns about the THAAD system.The THAAD system is a US-made missile defense system that is capable of shooting down ballistic missiles in mid-flight. The system has been deployed in South Korea for several years, but it has also been the subject of criticism from China, which has expressed concerns that it could compromise its own national security.The US official said that the dialogue with China would aim to address those concerns and to ensure that the THAAD system was not a threat to the security of the region. The official added that the US was committed to working with its allies in the region to maintain stability and security in the face of North Korean threats.The news of the US-China dialogue on THAAD came as tensions between the two countries continue to escalate over a range of issues, including trade and human rights. However, the official said that the THAAD dialogue was a separate issue and that it was not intended to be a bargaining chip in broader negotiations between the two countries.The THAAD system has been a flashpoint in US-China relations in recent years, and the decision to engage in dialogue with Beijing is likely to be welcomed by many in the region who are concerned about the escalating tensions between the two countries.While the exact details of the dialogue have yet to be worked out, the US official said that the US was committed to finding a resolution that would be acceptable to all parties involved.

As the Philippine government prepares to submit its position paper on the South China Sea dispute to an international tribunal, the United States and China are watching closely, with each waiting to see how the Manila leader will tackle the sensitive issue.The Philippines is one of several Southeast Asian nations embroiled in a territorial row with China over the South China Sea, a vital shipping lane and potential source of vast oil and gas reserves. The Philippines' position paper is expected to be a crucial document in the case it filed last year at the International Tribunal for the Law of the Sea (ITLOS).US officials say they are closely monitoring the situation, with some suggesting that the Philippines' stance could influence Washington's own approach to the territorial dispute. Meanwhile, Chinese officials have dismissed the ITLOS case as "meaningless" and reiterated their position that the South China Sea is a "core interest" of the nation.China's assertiveness in the South China Sea has raised concerns among its neighbors and the United States, which has accused Beijing of using coercion and intimidation to advance its territorial claims. The Philippines, backed by the US, has challenged China's territorial claims in the South China Sea, including its vast island-building activities in the disputed waters.While the Philippines has been careful not to antagonize China, President Benigno Aquino III has said his country will not back down from asserting its rights in the South China Sea.

Ivanka Trump's brand has been on a roll despite the controversies surrounding her father's political career. UN Secretary-General Ban Ki-moon has warned North Korea against launching a rocket, saying it would be a "provocative act" that would heighten tensions in the region.Ban made the remarks on Wednesday in response to a question about North Korea's plan to launch a long-range rocket between April 12 and 16 to celebrate the 100th birthday of the country's founder, Kim Il Sung."I urge North Korea to refrain from proceeding with the launch," Ban said. "It would be a very unhelpful and provocative act, which would heighten tensions in the region and affect the international community as a whole."The UN chief emphasized that the use of ballistic missile technology would violate existing UN Security Council resolutions, and could have serious consequences for the Korean Peninsula and the region as a whole.North Korea announced its plan to launch the rocket earlier this month, saying it was necessary to put a satellite into orbit as part of its space program. However, the move is widely seen as a disguised test of its long-range missile technology.The US, Japan, South Korea, and other countries have urged North Korea to abandon its plans, warning of possible consequences if the launch goes ahead.The Security Council has called for the launch to be postponed or cancelled, and has urged North Korea to respect its international obligations and commitments.Ban stressed that the international community had invested heavily in the denuclearization of the Korean Peninsula, and urged all parties to continue working towards this goal."

"International aid offers have been presented to the government of Zimbabwe, but the aid is being reviewed by the country's leaders. A local mosque leader has resigned after comments made by the imam suggesting genital mutilation of women was acceptable sparked outrage in the community.The imam's remarks were made during a Friday sermon and were widely criticised by members of the mosque and the wider community.In a statement, the mosque leader said: "I am deeply saddened by the imam's comments and I strongly condemn them. Washington, DC - US lawmakers are pushing for more sanctions on Russia, citing its "menacing behavior" around the world.Senate Majority Leader Mitch McConnell announced on Tuesday that he will work with the Senate Foreign Relations Committee to develop new sanctions against Russia. This comes as tensions between the two nations continue to escalate over issues such as Ukraine and election interference."We must take steps to deter Russia's aggressive behavior, including its interference in other countries' elections and its violation of international norms," McConnell said in a statement.The move is supported by both Democrats and Republicans, who agree that Russia poses a significant threat to US national security."We have been too slow to impose consequences on Russia for their bad behavior," said Senator Lindsey Graham, a Republican from South Carolina. "We are living in a new world where Russia is trying to break us apart, and we need to take steps to protect our democracy."The new sanctions are expected to target Russia's energy sector, as well as its defense and intelligence sectors. They may also include measures to limit Russia's access to the global financial system.The Trump administration has not yet commented on the proposed sanctions, but it is expected to support the measure. The White House has previously imposed several rounds of sanctions on Russia over its actions in Ukraine and interference in the 2016 US election.The US has been trying to build a coalition of nations to impose sanctions on Russia, but some countries, such as Germany, have been hesitant to impose harsh penalties on Russia.The US lawmakers' move comes as tensions between the US and Russia continue to escalate.

President of the United States of America, George W. Bush, has called on all parties involved in the ongoing conflict in South Ossetia to immediately cease all acts of violence and to work towards finding a peaceful resolution to the crisis. Tunisian Prime Minister Mohammed Jomaa has announced the formation of a new government, the third government in the space of a year.The new government will consist of 27 ministers, including 14 new faces, and will be sworn in later today.The announcement was made by Jomaa at a press conference this morning, where he said that the new government would prioritize economic and social development, and work to strengthen national unity.The Prime Minister also stressed the importance of improving living standards for all Tunisians, and said that the new government would be committed to promoting gender equality and protecting the rights of women and children.Jomaa's predecessor, Habib Essid, had resigned last month following a period of political instability and economic challenges.The new government will face significant challenges, including reining in inflation, creating jobs and boosting economic growth.However, Jomaa expressed confidence that the new government would be able to meet these challenges and bring stability to Tunisia.

Nigerian troops and Boko Haram fighters clashed at a wedding party in the northeastern state of Borno, military sources said on Tuesday.The incident occurred on Sunday evening when soldiers were called to the town of Chibok to quell a protest by residents angry at the military's inability to find the more than 200 schoolgirls kidnapped by Boko Haram in April.While the troops were at the wedding party, they were attacked by Boko Haram gunmen, who were also at the event. A firefight ensued, resulting in an unknown number of casualties."The terrorists attacked the troops while they were attending a wedding ceremony," a military source told Reuters. "There was a firefight, but I cannot give you the casualty figure now."Boko Haram, whose name means "Western education is forbidden," has been waging a campaign of violence against civilians and government targets in its quest to establish an Islamic state in Nigeria's north.

Actor Tim Conway, best known for his work on the popular TV variety show "The Carol Burnett Show," has died at the age of 85, according to his publicist. Conway, who was born in Ohio in 1933, rose to fame in the 1960s and '70s for his comedic skits and impersonations on Burnett's show. He was a beloved cast member and won two Emmy Awards for his work on the show.Conway's career spanned decades, and he appeared in many movies and TV shows over the years. He was also a successful stand-up comedian and performed in numerous comedy specials.He is survived by his wife, Charlene, and their three children. A private funeral will be held in Los Angeles, where Conway had lived for many years.Conway's passing is a loss to the entertainment industry and his fans around the world. He will be remembered for his quick wit, clever humor, and the joy he brought to millions of viewers through his work on "The Carol Burnett Show." Our thoughts and condolences go out to his family and loved ones during this difficult time.

HUNDREDS OF BODIES FOUND IN MASS GRAVES NEAR SYRIA EX-IS BASTIONA chilling discovery has been made in Syria, with the uncovering of several mass graves containing the remains of hundreds of individuals near the former stronghold of the Islamic State (IS) group.The graves were discovered by local residents and members of a Syrian Democratic Forces (SDF) alliance, who were clearing the area of mines and unexploded ordnance. The Yazidis are a minority group in the region, and their treatment by IS was considered one of the group's worst crimes.The discovery of the mass graves is just the latest in a long line of horrific findings in Syria, where the country's civil war has resulted in countless atrocities and war crimes. The conflict has left hundreds of thousands of people dead, and millions more displaced.As the world continues to grapple with the ongoing humanitarian crisis in Syria, the discovery of these mass graves serves as a stark reminder of the devastating impact of the conflict on innocent civilians.

COTTAGE GROVE, Okla. – Astronaut Drew Morgan, a Cottage Grove native, is making headlines for his unique view of his hometown.Morgan, who recently returned from a year at the International Space Station, shared a photo on social media of a corn maze in Oklahoma that he took from space. The photo shows the intricate design of the maze, which is shaped like an astronaut, and is clearly visible from the ISS."I was blown away by how clear the image was," Morgan said in a statement. "I could see every detail of the maze, even from that high up. It's amazing to think that something like this could be created in my hometown."The corn maze, located on the family farm of the Morgans, has become a popular attraction in the small town of Cottage Grove.

As the Association of Southeast Asian Nations (ASEAN) prepares for its 23rd Summit in Bangkok, Thailand, analysts say that the future of democracy in the region hinges on the success of the country's democratic process.The ASEAN, a regional intergovernmental organization comprising ten countries in Southeast Asia, has long been criticized for its lack of progress in democratization. The bloc has faced challenges in fostering a culture of democracy, particularly in countries like Myanmar and Cambodia where authoritarian regimes have been entrenched for decades.However, with Thailand serving as the host of the upcoming ASEAN Summit, analysts are looking to the country as a potential catalyst for democratic progress in the region. Thailand has a history of democratic governance, with the country enjoying over a decade of elected civilian governments before the military seized power in a 2014 coup.Since then, Thailand has faced a tumultuous political landscape, with the military-backed government facing criticism for its human rights record and suppression of dissent. The country's democratic process has been hindered by legal challenges, boycotts, and election delays, leading some to question whether the country will be able to hold a fair and free election in the near future.Despite these challenges, analysts say that the success of the ASEAN Summit in Thailand could signal a turning point for democracy in the region. The summit provides an opportunity for the country to showcase its commitment to democracy and its ability to host a successful international event.If the summit is deemed a success, it could provide a boost to Thailand's democratic process and encourage other ASEAN countries to follow suit.

Washington, D.C. – In a speech at the University of Colorado Boulder, President Barack Obama announced changes to the student loan system in an effort to ease the burden on borrowers.The changes include lowering interest rates on student loans, expanding eligibility for income-based repayment plans and providing loan forgiveness to those who work in public service."We believe in the value of education. We believe in making sure that higher education is accessible to all people," Obama said.Obama also proposed a new plan that would allow borrowers to cap their monthly payments at 10% of their discretionary income, with the remaining balance of their debt forgiven after 20 years.The president also said the government will work to prevent student loan servicers from engaging in "misleading and deceptive" practices, following accusations of widespread abuse by borrowers.The changes will take effect this summer, and will be implemented by the Department of Education."It's not just about making sure that our young people have access to higher education. It's also about making sure that they have access to the American Dream," Obama said.

Israel has welcomed the Arab League's call for Israeli-Palestinian talks, after months of diplomatic deadlock. . Washington, DC - US officials have announced that the missing Malaysian airliner may have crashed into the Indian Ocean. The announcement comes after an intense search for the missing plane, which disappeared without a trace on March 8th.According to sources close to the investigation, the US Navy and Air Force have detected a possible debris field in the Indian Ocean, which is consistent with the wreckage of a commercial airplane. As the world faces the increasingly dire effects of climate change, experts are warning that the impacts are coming sooner and faster than previously thought.According to a new report from the Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change (IPCC), global warming is likely to cause a 10-fold increase in the frequency of heat waves by the end of the century, putting millions of people at risk of heat-related illnesses and death.In addition to the rising temperatures, the IPCC report also predicts that climate change will lead to more frequent and intense natural disasters, such as hurricanes, floods, and droughts. This will have devastating effects on communities and infrastructure around the world.The report also highlights the potential for sea-level rise, which could displace millions of people and cause extensive damage to coastal cities and ecosystems.These are just a few examples of the numerous and severe impacts of climate change that the IPCC report warns us about. It is clear that we must take immediate action to reduce greenhouse gas emissions and prevent the worst effects of climate change from becoming a reality.

Havana, Cuba - Cuban President Miguel Díaz-Canel has announced his support for same-sex marriage, a significant shift in the country's stance on LGBT rights.Speaking at a press conference, Díaz-Canel stated that he believed "that all people have the right to equality and to have their rights respected, regardless of their sexual orientation." He added that he believed that "it's time for Cuba to move forward and to recognize same-sex marriage."This announcement comes as a surprise to many, as Cuba has historically been viewed as a relatively progressive nation when it comes to LGBT rights. The country has had a number of openly gay and transgender politicians, and it has also decriminalized homosexuality.However, same-sex marriage is not yet legal in Cuba. The country's current laws do not recognize same-sex unions, and same-sex couples do not have the same legal rights as heterosexual couples.Díaz-Canel's announcement is being hailed as a major step forward for LGBT rights in Cuba. Many hope that this will lead to the legalization of same-sex marriage in the country, and that it will also lead to increased recognition and protection of the rights of LGBT individuals.Cuba is not the only country in the region to be taking steps towards legalizing same-sex marriage.

Former EU Trade Chief Pascal Lamy Appointed to Head World Trade OrganizationGeneva, September 9thThe World Trade Organization (WTO) has announced the appointment of former European Union (EU) Trade Commissioner Pascal Lamy as its new Director-General. Lamy, who served as EU Trade Commissioner for 14 years before stepping down in October 2014, will take up his new role on September 15th, succeeding outgoing Director-General Roberto Azevedo.Lamy, 65, is considered to be a seasoned trade negotiator, with extensive experience in global trade policy. He played a key role in shaping the EU's trade policy during his tenure as Trade Commissioner, overseeing the conclusion of several major trade agreements, including the EU-US Transatlantic Trade and Investment Partnership (TTIP) and the EU-Canada Comprehensive Economic and Trade Agreement (CETA).In his new role as Director-General of the WTO, Lamy will be responsible for overseeing the organization's efforts to promote free and fair trade among its 164 member states. He will be tasked with fostering cooperation among WTO members, resolving trade disputes, and ensuring that the organization's rules and procedures are followed.Commenting on his appointment, Lamy said he was "honored and delighted" to take up the role, and added that he was "committed to working with all WTO members to promote a rules-based trading system that is fair, inclusive, and responsive to the needs of all."The WTO's membership welcomed the appointment of Lamy, with many praising his experience and expertise in global trade policy.

The French far-right National Front (FN) has revealed that it received financial support from Russian sources. Many politicians and commentators have called for an investigation into the FN's funding sources and for stricter regulations on foreign political donations.The FN has yet to comment on the revelation, but has in the past denied receiving foreign funding. The party has also accused its opponents of trying to smear its reputation.

United States Suspends All Economic Sanctions on BurmaWashington, DC - In a historic move, the United States has announced the suspension of all economic sanctions on Burma. The move had been widely criticized by the international community, with many calling for an end to the sanctions in order to promote a peaceful and prosperous Burma.The announcement has been welcomed by political leaders and human rights activists alike, who see it as a significant step towards promoting democracy and human rights in the Southeast Asian nation. Boston, MA - In a move to quell the growing protest movement, Boston Police arrested dozens of "Occupy Boston" demonstrators early this morning.The arrests came as a surprise to the protesters who had been camped out in Dewey Square for the past two weeks. A recent spate of killings in Bangladesh has sparked concern about the country's secular traditions and the future of religious and ethnic minorities.In the past month, at least 10 people have been hacked to death in Bangladesh, most of them online critics of religious extremism. It is important for the government and people of Bangladesh to stand up for their secular values and protect the rights of all citizens, regardless of their religious or ethnic background.

Dozens of protesters were arrested in Indonesia's Papua region this week, as tensions continue to boil over in the restive region.The arrests were made on Monday and Tuesday, as demonstrations against the government turned violent.Protesters had gathered to demand more autonomy for the region, which has long been a flashpoint for political and ethnic tensions.Clashes with security forces left several people injured, and the government declared a state of emergency in the area.The arrests came as the government announced a series of concessions to the region, including increased funding for infrastructure projects and increased representation in the regional government.However, many Papuans feel that these concessions do not go far enough, and that the region is still not receiving a fair share of resources and representation.The situation in Papua remains tense, with many calling for greater autonomy or even independence from the Indonesian government.The arrests are the latest in a series of incidents in the region, which has a long history of political and ethnic conflict.The government has pledged to investigate the violence and hold those responsible accountable.However, many in the region are skeptical that the government will take meaningful action to address the root causes of the conflict.The situation in Papua is likely to continue to be a flashpoint for political and ethnic tensions in the coming months.

Thousands of people have been evacuated from the city of Prescott, Arizona, as a massive wildfire threatens to engulf the area. The fire, which started on Sunday, has already burned through over 16,000 acres of land and is spreading quickly.Residents of the city have been advised to leave immediately, with many fleeing to nearby towns and cities for safety. The fire has destroyed several homes and businesses, and firefighters have been struggling to contain it.The exact cause of the fire is still unknown, but officials believe it was started by lightning. High winds and dry conditions have made it difficult for firefighters to contain the blaze, and the weather forecast is not helping, with temperatures expected to reach as high as 90 degrees Fahrenheit in the coming days.Emergency services are currently on high alert, with firefighters from several surrounding areas being called in to help battle the blaze. The situation is being closely monitored by local officials, who are urging residents to stay safe and avoid the area if possible.In addition to the wildfire, the state of Arizona has been experiencing a heat wave, with temperatures soaring to over 100 degrees in some areas.

WASHINGTON - John McCain is not signing off quietly.As in so much of the senator's extraordinary life, the rebellious Republican is facing this challenging chapter -- battling brain cancer -- in his own rule-breaking way, stirring up old fights and starting new ones. Rarely has the sickbed been so lively.McCain is promoting a new book, delivering a counterpunch of ideals contrary to President Donald Trump's running of the White House. McCain's long-distance rejection of CIA director nominee Gina Haspel's history with torture goaded former Vice President Dick Cheney into a fresh debate over waterboarding and other now-banned interrogation techniques. On Friday, friends rallied to defend McCain against a White House official's cruel joke that his positions don't matter because ``he's dying anyway.''If this is Washington's long goodbye to a sometimes favorite son, it's also a reemergence of old resentments and political fault lines that continue to split the nation.Perhaps no one should have expected anything less from the 81-year-old senator, who can be crotchety and cantankerous but is also seen by many, both in and out of politics, as an American hero, flaws and all.Former Vice President Joe Biden said Friday as McCain ``fights for his life, he deserves better -- so much better.''``Our children learn from our example,'' Biden said. ``The lingering question is: Whose example will it be? I am certain it will be John's.''Said House Speaker Paul Ryan, ``His legacy is so long that John McCain is a hero to us all.''

Thousands of Austrians are protesting their country's new right-wing government with a march in Vienna. Police in the capital said about 20,000 people were attending the march on Saturday. Some protesters carried placards reading "Never Again." Others chanted slogans such as "Refugees should stay, drive out the Nazis." The new governing coalition made up of the conservative Austrian People's Party and the nationalist Freedom Party has taken a hard line against migration.

LONDON - President Donald Trump on Friday declared the U.S. relationship with Britain as “the highest level of special,” rejecting reports of troubled ties further frayed by his comments published in one of the highest-circulation newspapers in this country.Standing alongside the British prime minister outside her Chequers country estate, Trump defended his remarks in the newspaper interview, which were seen as further weakening Theresa May’s hold on power.“It didn’t put in what I said about the prime minister and I said tremendous things,” Trump replied to a question about critical remarks he made in an interview with The Sun.WATCH: Brits Protest Trump VisitThe conservative British newspaper itself characterized Trump’s printed remarks as pouring nitroglycerine on the already raging revolt against the prime minister by Brexit hardliners in May’s own party.“They didn’t put it in the headline," Trump said about positive comments he made about May during the interview. "I wish they put it in the headline."Trump then alluded to “fake news,” but he did not specifically deny any of his comments printed by the newspaper, whose Friday morning headline blared: “May has wrecked Brexit…US deal is off!”But Trump on Friday afternoon said that after his discussions with May and her aides, he now believes a post-Brexit free trade agreement between Washington and London is “absolutely possible.”

Ukraine's emergencies ministry says 16 miners have been killed in an explosion at a mine in the country's east.The ministry said three other miners were injured in the blast early Friday morning and hospitalized, while nine were missing. The explosion occurred at a mine in the Luhansk region.

BRUSSELS - By the time he made it from Syria to Europe, 25-year-old Mulham, like many new arrivals, was already distrustful of authorities.In Croatia, for example, police told his group they were going to a hotel to shower and sleep.Instead, they were locked inside what smelled like a large barn, and held for seven hours."I asked the police what was happening," Mulham said later as we drank coffee at a ramshackle café near a refugee camp in Belgium."The officer told me: We don't want you,” he said. "The world doesn't want you.'"But Mulham feels that, with a degree in architecture and the strength and resources to escape Syria, the comment is unjust. "I will be useful after all," he asserted.As tanks roll through the streets of Brussels, and heavily armed officers patrol areas they believe will be targeted in what the government calls an "imminent threat" of a terrorist attack or attacks, Mulham remains skeptical.Refugees play football Nov. 23, 2015, near a Brussels camp. The soldiers and tanks guarding the city were not in the neighborhood. (Heather Murdock/VOA)Many Syrian refugees are afraid of the attacks and depressed to be facing the threat of violence again after fleeing a brutal war, he said. But Mulham and many others simply don't believe there is a threat."They want to make the people afraid of us," he said, mulling alternate reasons for the show of force. He considers another possibility: Authorities want to make refugees afraid of backlash from the local people.And that is the impact the heightened alert is having, regardless of the reason for it, said 19-year-old Adel, a Syrian refugee in Belgium who hopes to one day play football (soccer) professionally.

U.S. President George Bush is urging an end to the fighting in Georgia's breakaway province of South Ossetia. VOA White House correspondent Paula Wolfson reports from Beijing, where Mr. Bush is attending the Olympic Games.President Bush says the fighting must stop."I am deeply concerned about the situation in Georgia," he said. "The United States takes this matter very seriously."He says he is particularly troubled by the fact the conflict is spreading to other parts of Georgia - a reference to Russian bombings beyond the borders of South Ossetia."The violence is endangering regional peace," said President Bush. "Civilian lives have been lost and others are endangered."South Ossetia's autonomous status was abolished by the Georgian government in 1990, then reinstated in 1992. The current government in Tblisi has vowed to bring it back into the fold and on Thursday launched a military operation to do just that.But South Ossetia has strong ties to Moscow, which supports the separatist movement. When Georgia sent its forces in, the Russians responded by sending in more troops and bombers.President Bush says all sides need to step back, stop hostilities, and work with mediators to resolve the conflict."Georgia is a sovereign nation and its territorial integrity must be respected," he said. "We have urged an immediate halt to the violence and a stand-down by all troops."White House officials say President Bush re-enforced the U.S. position in separate conversations with Russian President Dmitri Medvedev, and Georgian President Mikhail Saakashvili. In his brief comments to reporters in Beijing, Mr. Bush called on Russia to stop bombing and start cooperating with peace efforts."

Into his life stumbles young Melody who moved from her rural Southern home to New York City to find fame and fortune, but instead finds herself out on the street. Boris, despite his outward bluster, has a good heart and he takes her in: to save her life and to impart his unquestionable wisdom.Into his life stumbles young Melody who moved from her rural Southern home to New York City to find fame and fortune, but instead finds herself out on the street. Boris, despite his outward bluster, has a good heart and he takes her in: to save her life and to impart his unquestionable wisdom.It is not exactly the match made in heaven; but, as the title says, "Whatever Works."Evan Rachel Wood plays naïve Melody."I don't want to sound pompous saying it, but it was really hard to play dumb," Wood says. "I was worried that she was going to be really annoying or really endearing. It was a fine line there that I didn't want to cross, but I think she is sweet.""She played someone who is much dumber than who she is and I played someone who is much, much smarter, so we were at both ends, " adds Larry David, a co-creator of the hit TV series "Seinfeld" and star of his own TV comedy show "Curb Your Enthusiasm". David is Boris. He says his lines are unmistakably from Woody Allen, but insists that his character is not a surrogate for the writer-director."I never considered for a second that I would be playing him," David says.

NEW DELHI - The U.S. Ambassador to India has met Indian opposition leader Narendra Modi, ending a near decade-long boycott of the man who is the frontrunner to be India’s next prime minister. The Hindu nationalist leader was denied a U.S. visa in 2005 over his role in sectarian violence which swept his state in 2002. Television pictures showed U.S. Ambassador to India Nancy Powell and Bharatiya Janata Party leader Narendra Modi exchanging a cordial handshake before they sat down for discussions Thursday in Gandhinagar, the capital of Gujarat state headed by the Indian opposition leader. Political analysts said the handshake was prompted by the possibility that Modi could head India’s next government. He is the prime ministerial candidate of the opposition B.J.P., which polls show could dislodge the Congress party in upcoming national elections, to be held by May. The U.S. was among several countries which shunned the B.J.P. leader over allegations that he did not do enough to stop riots which swept through Gujarat in 2002 and killed nearly 1,000 people, mostly Muslims. Modi denies the accusations. The Supreme Court has found no evidence to prosecute him. As he grew in prominence on India’s national political stage in the last year, other countries and international bodies, including the European Union and Australia, restored ties with him. Former Indian ambassador to the United States Lalit Mansingh said the U.S. was bound to follow suit. “It would be quite embarrassing for the Americans not to recognize a democratically elected leader.

The former president of Somalia's Transitional Federal Government has died at a hospital in the United Arab Emirates at the age of 77 following a long battle with liver disease. Abdullahi Yusuf Ahmed, a former warlord, was elected president in 2004, but had few friends left in Somalia by the time he resigned four years later.Abdullahi Yusuf Ahmed spent a lifetime fighting. He famously led an attempt to overthrow Somali President Mohammed Siad Barre in 1978, but failed, fled to Kenya and then to Ethiopia. There, he formed a rebel force to fight against the Barre regime.But the Ethiopians turned against him and he was imprisoned in the mid-1980s until 1991, when Siad Barre was finally forced from power.The Somalia he went home to was chaotic and violent.

Lithuanian officials have transferred French rock singer Bertrand Cantat from a prison hospital to a prison cell as they continue the investigation into his role in the death of actress Marie Trintignant.Officials approved the move following improvement in Cantat's mental state. Prosecutors in the capital, Vilnius, filed charges last week against the lead singer of the French band Noir Desir for the beating death of the French actress, the singer's girlfriend.Cantat allegedly inflicted head injuries on Trintignant, 41, during a conflict in a Vilnius hotel. Her family had her flown to Paris, where she died of the injuries earlier this month. The actress was in Lithuania shooting a film about the life of French writer Colette, which was being directed by her mother, Nadine.Cantat has admitted being drunk and arguing with Marie, but called her death a horrible accident.

: What has sparked your imagination recently? The poems in this month’s issue of Poetry Magazine are about things happening in Africa, but that’s not the sole focus of your work. What has sparked your imagination recently?PATEL: Well I divide my time between Kenya, my home country and Oakland, California. And of course in these times anyone who is thinking realizes that national borders have very little relevance to the global crises that are affecting us – climate crisis for one thing. It does not respect national or state or continental borders. So in this moment the most urgent and stimulating issue that’s driving my work is really the planetary crisis we’re in and how we come together as humanity to address it.Click here to hear David Byrd's interview with Shailja Patel on poetry.Some of that crisis is man-made, situations like the takeover in Crimea or the Central African Republic or the situation in Afghanistan as they are heading toward elections. Does that inspire you more than just the general situation of humanity or do you find that these things pop up and you are almost compelled to write about them.PATEL: I believe one of the most important things I do with my work is to connect the dots between what we think of as political or geopolitical conflict, and the struggle – the fundamental struggle – over resources.
At least one suicide bomber attacked a mosque on the outskirts of Maiduguri, Nigeria, killing at least 22 people and wounding another 17.

Pakistani Taliban fighters have begun withdrawing from a key northwestern district, where the government deployed extra forces to stop the militants from advancing closer to the capital, Islamabad. A top administrator in the region, Syed Mohammed Javed, said Taliban militants are pulling out of Buner district and returning to their stronghold in the nearby Swat Valley. Emergency meeting heldPakistan's Army chief General Ashfaq Kiyani held an emergency meeting Friday with commanders in the region to discuss a military operation in Buner and Swat. Later, General Kiyani released a statement, saying the army "will not allow the militants to dictate terms to the government, or impose their way of life on the civil society of Pakistan." He also said the pause in military operations that followed a recent peace deal with the Taliban in the region is "not a concession to the militants."Hundreds of paramilitary troops were deployed to Buner after Taliban militants began setting up checkpoints in the district, less than 100 kilometers from Islamabad.Peace deal includes Sharia The peace deal between the government and hard-line cleric Sufi Mohammed allows the imposition of Islamic law (Sharia) in parts of Malakand division, including Swat Valley. In exchange, militants agreed to lay down their weapons. That has not happened yet. This week, U.S. Secretary of State Hillary Clinton accused the Pakistani government of ceding more territory to the Taliban. She described the situation as a "mortal threat" to the United States and the world. Taliban militants from Pakistan's Swat valley have begun leaving Buner, the district some 100 kilometers from the capital that they took over last week.

The U.S. Food and Drug Administration would like to see food-processing companies and restaurants reduce the amount of salt in their food by one-third over the next 10 years.The draft guidelines issued Wednesday are voluntary, but the FDA hopes that reducing the sodium in Americans' meals will help fight high blood pressure, or hypertension, which is estimated to kill 1,000 people every day in the U.S.“The link between sodium consumption and blood pressure is strong and well documented," FDA's official blog said. ”High blood pressure is a key risk factor for heart disease and stroke. There is strong agreement among expert bodies such as the Institute of Medicine on the need to reduce consumption to less than 2,300 milligrams per day [mg/day].”The average American currently consumes 3,400 milligrams of sodium each day.The problem is not so much with the salt people sprinkle on their food, but rather the excessive sodium that is pre-loaded in food by manufacturers.One of the most respected American public-health experts, Dr. Thomas Frieden of the government's Centers for Disease Control and Prevention, endorsed limits on sodium intake in an online editorial published Wednesday by JAMA, The Journal of the American Medical Association.Frieden said a 12 percent reduction in dietary sodium could prevent 32,000 heart attacks and 20,000 strokes every year.“

KAFR ZIADA, EGYPT/DUBAI - Rice farmers in Kafr Ziada village in the Nile River Delta have ignored planting restrictions aimed at conserving water for years, continuing to grow a medium-grain variety of the crop that is prized around the Arab world.A decision thousands of kilometers to the south is about to change that, however, in another example of how concern about water, one of the world's most valuable commodities, is forcing change in farming, laws and even international diplomacy.Far upstream, close to one of the sources of the Nile, Ethiopia is preparing to fill the reservoir behind its new $4 billion Grand Renaissance Dam, possibly as soon as this year.FILE - A general view of Ethiopia's Grand Renaissance Dam, as it undergoes construction, is seen during a media tour along the river Nile in Benishangul Gumuz Region, Guba Woreda, in Ethiopia, March 31, 2015.How fast it does so could have devastating consequences for farmers who have depended on the Nile for millennia to irrigate strategic crops for Egypt's 96 million people, expected to grow to 128 million by 2030.

The UN Food and Agriculture Organization says nearly 12 million people are in need of emergency food assistance in southern Africa. Most of them are in Zimbabwe and Malawi.In its final African food security report of the year, the FAO says the problem continues despite a bumper maize harvest in South Africa. Dr. Shukri Ahmed is an economist with the FAO?s Global Information and Early Warning System. From Rome, he first spoke to English to Africa reporter Joe De Capua about the food shortages in Zimbabwe.?The main issue apart from the drought and certain parts that had been affected, there were micro-economic situations that have compounded and certainly policy issues that have compounded the problem affecting so many people. The food security situation there remains very serious. One is the insufficient grain supply on the market. The import requirement is huge?would the country be able to import that. If the country imports, would the people (be able to) afford to buy that. Do they have the purchasing power? What is the employment situation? What is the income situation? So all these factors have been compounding the overall food supply situation in the country,? he says.The situation also continues to worsen in Malawi. Dr. Ahmed blames that on ?a combination of factors.
